Award.AwardTitle: Scaling Up: Joint Workshops on Continental-Scale Population and Community Ecology and Education
Award.AbstractNarration: Opportunities to address new scientific questions at continental scales have been growing enormously over the past decade or so, as new networks and knowledgebases are developed and deployed at a rapid rate. While ecosystem ecologists are used to addressing questions on such scales (productivity of biomes, global nitrogen cycles), population and community ecologists have less experience working at these spatial scales. The award provides funds to support two joint, co-occurring workshops, one for early-career population and community ecologists to develop research plans for continental scale questions on population and community ecology, and the other for undergraduate students to explore ways to apply continental and regional scale knowledgebases and tools to environmental policy issues. The proposed workshops would bring large scale data and analytical tools to the attention of young career scientists and undergraduates in population and community ecology. Practitioners at landscape and ecosystem levels are more comfortable with these tools, but population and community ecologists need to be encourages to explore questions at larger scales than plots and transects. The award will enable a broader movement in ecology towards the use of networks, global knowledgebases and distributed public data. The workshops will provide training, ideas, and collaborative network for students and early career scientists who wish to 'scale-up' in the questions addressed in community and population ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award engaged faculty and students from diverse disciplines and cultural heritages to explore how current environmental challenges are related to human systems using large datasets containing both socioeconomic and ecological data from publicly available sources. Participants were able to evaluate different human and policy responses to environmental challenges, enhance their understanding of ecological principles, and develop research questions to explore how ecosystem services (food, fiber, air, water, and energy), quality of life, and economics are related. Using GIS, student participants analyzed spatially explicit interactions between policy, land-use and land-cover change, and ecosystems. Through the student workshop, “Scaling Up: Future of Environmental Decisions, A Workshop for Students,” participants were introduced to the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) infrastructure project, provided opportunities to gain 21st century skills in data/mapping technologies and public communications, network with local organizations, and explore potential ecology and environmental science careers.

Further, ESA partnered with the Quantitative Undergraduate Biology Education and Synthesis (QUBES) project and recruited faculty especially from minority-serving institutions and primarily undergraduate institutions to implement the concept of ecological scale in undergraduate education through 1) existing teaching resources from ESA’s Teaching Issues and Experiments in Ecology (TIEE) education journal and 2) the development of new teaching resources that will be submitted to TIEE for publication.  These resources provide models for curriculum that will utilize NEON data in education in the near future. 

Both the student workshop and the faculty mentoring networks resulted in deeper appreciation related to data use, including: data management, data relevance, data scale, data skepticism and data tools. In particular, nearly 96% of all participants in the Scaling Up student workshop indicated they learned how NEON data will be able to help address environmental management solutions. This will help the field to understand ways to utilize NEON data once available, and to help NEON gain insight on data products that will be useful for education and to society.

The faculty workshop, “Scaling Up: Population and Community Ecology, A Workshop for Early-Career Scientists” brought together early-career ecologists (no more than eight years post-Ph.D.) who work in community and population ecology to identify key questions in these fields that can be addressed at continental scales. These young scientists explored what existing tools and knowledge exist to conduct such research and identified needs for new tools to address continental-scale questions. Following the workshop, as described in an article in the ESA Bulletin, participants stayed in touch with their working groups, and several groups developed papers for publication in peer-reviewed journals. Participants also reported back to the workshop organizers that the opportunity to interact with such a diverse and interdisciplinary group of peers helped further their understanding of how to use continental-scale data.

In conclusion, these combined workshops provided students a valuable opportunity to learn how to use large scale data and understand its practical applications, and gave researchers accustomed to working at relatively small spatial scales a new understanding of how to scale up their research to continental levels, and helped them form new research collaborations.
